The Johns Hopkins University this week revealed immediate and long-range plans for the development of the
Homewood campus which tentatively include Wyman
Park.
Expected to cover a period extending into the next
century, the development program lists 27 separate items
of enlarged and added facilities which will cause a minimum alteration in the present outlay of the campus. ,
The program is contingent upon the acquisition of a
73-acre tract of Wyman Park immediately west of campus.

The much-discussed third dormitory, scheduled to be built by
this spring and to house 285
students, has been "deferred," in
view of the lack of '"immediate
demand," according to Johns
Hopkins University Plant Manager Wesley A. Taylor.
Mr. Taylor said that questionnaires had been sent out to all
graduate students and post-doctoral students and fraternities in
order to determine just how
many students could be expected
to move into the new dorm.
Replies revealed that the demand was "not in itself sufficient
to justify the University's going

immediately,"

bigotry. Indeed, these are many
vehemently called for concerted action to end this "repugnant practice" before the events of February 22.
Criticism from many quarters has been heaped upon
those students who led that stormy sit-in protest. The
action has been called rash, hurried, disorganized, unnecessary, etc. Yet where were all these "moderates"
with better methods of solving this knotty problem before
the demonstration?
One need not march with the sit-in group, or even
support such action. But as long as one is truly interested
in securing the, human rights of one's fellow students,
indeed, one's fellow man, one must recognize the efficacy
of the sit-in. For without the demonstration the problem
of discrimination would never have even entered the
minds of the great majority of people, the problem would
never have even been discussed in the numerous brotherhood meetings, and the many fine suggestions for less
dramatic action would never have been presented. Even
if the sit-in did not accomplish integration in one day,
it has accomplished a great deal in so far as it has brought
the problem to the surface for all to see and discuss.
It is unfortunate that so many individuals have taken
this opportunity to heap scorn on the sit-in when, indeed;
they owe a vote of thanks to it for calling attention to the
situation. The very fact that most have combined their
criticism with very informative, helpful alternative suggestions proves the effectiveness of the demonstration.
These suggestions would have never been put forth
otherwise.
One of the most discouraging aspects Of this affair
is the amazitig display of cowardice on the part of so
many when it came to taking action or voicing one's approval or disapproval of the situation. Many pre-sit-in
liberals smiled a cowardly refusal when asked to sign a
petition asserting their objection to discrimination. Why,
if one truly possesses the ideals and feelings that so many
claim to possess, must one cravenly hide them and reserve
them only for trusted friends—especially when one could
accomplish so much by speaking out freely.—B.R.

it was a dullish evening.
Suddenly Dolores Vladnay stood up and stamped her foot.
"Chaps," she said to her sorors,"this is too yawn-making! Let's

At this point, in walked a young pledge named Alice Bluegown. "Excuse me, mistresses," said she, tugging her forelock,
"I have finished making your,beds, doing your homework, and
ironing your pleats. Will there be anything else?"
"Yes," snapped Dolores Vladna,y. "When I count to three,
you will be hypnotized."
"Yes, excellency," said Alice, bobbing a curtsey.
"One, two, three," said Dolores.
Alice promptly went into a trance.
"Go back," said Dolores, "back into your childhood. Go
back to your fifth birthday, back to your birth, to before your
birth, to your last incarnation ... Now, who are you?"
"My name is Bridey Sigafoos," said Alice. "The year is 1818,
and I am in County Cork."
"Coo!" said the sorors.
"How old are you?" asked Dblores.
"I am seven," said Alice.
"Where is your mother?" asked Dolores.
"I don't know," said Alice. "She got sold at the fair last
Year."
"Coo!" said the sorors.
"Tell us about yourself," said Dolores.
"I am five feet tall," said Alice. "I have brown eyes, and I
Weigh 3200 pounds."
"Coo!" said the sorors.
"Isn't that rather heavy for a girl?" said Dolores.
!'Who's a girl?" said Alice. "I'm a black and white guernsey.'
"Coo!" said the sorors.
"Moo!" said Bridey Sigafoos.

Heavyweight JIM KELLEY grapples with his opponent as the Jay wrestlers prepped last
week for Saturday's Mason-Dixon Tournament. Kelley finished second in his division, being
pinned by Baltimore U.'s kingpin Bill Kohlhafer in the final round, as the Homewood matmen
came up with third place in the tourney standings.

Jay Grapplers Close Season;
Make Good Tourney Showing
hours before the start of the
tournament, Senior Co-captain
Marc Williams suffered a bone
chip in his right ankle which
put him on crutches. Roger Morrison, undoubtedly the strongest
and most versatile substitute in
the conference, suffered a torn
ligament and was out of action.

On Tuesday, February 23, the
Hopkins freshman
basketball
team concluded its season with
a 51-to-39 victory over the Dickinson College J.V. This win was
the Jays' sixth straight since the
mid-semester break and ended
the cagers' season with an 11-3
record.
The team had - many high
points over the campaign among
them the two wins over Loyola,
by 66-to-58 and the overtime win
64-to-62. Also outstanding in the
minds of those who followed the
fortunes of the frosh basketball
team were the overtime victory
over Franklin and Marshall
frosh, 78-to-74, the first victory
in three years against Baltimore
Junior College, 67-to-63, and
last of all the miraculous and
well-played two-point loss to the
Navy Plebes 59-57.

By HERB DORSEY

Guts. There might be nicer
ways to say it, but there isn't
a more descriptive way ... Guts
is what it took to work out for
two years with no official team,
sparse facilities, no letter awards,
no schedule, and sometimes not
even somebody else to wrestle
with, and guts carried the Hopkins wrestling team to third
place in the Mason-Dixon Conference tournament after the
team saw two of its best grapplers injured on the day before
the meet, automatically causing
the forfeiture of the 191-1b. class.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MARCH 4, 1960

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE EIGHT

BLUE JAY GRAPPLERS Frosh Dribblers End Year
POST WINNING SEASON With Victory For 11-3 Log
(Continued from Page 7)
his initial loss and from there on
he was very effective.
Jim Kelley, always the team
leader in no matter what sport
he plays, put on a superb exhibition of wrestling skill to capture the runner-up spot in the
Conference for the second year
in a row. Once again Baltimore
U's gargantuan Dick Kohlhafer,
who was voted the outstanding
tourney wrestler, pinned Kelley.
This heavyweight bout was undoubtedly the feature and highlight of the whole tournament.
For over four minutes, these
two fabulous performers traded
positions, while the crowd held
its breath. Kohlhafer, incidentally, has only failed to pin a
man once in his entire career,
and that man weighed 310
pounds. Kelley captured nine key
points for the Blue Jays, seven
for being runner-up and two for
his pair of previous falls, one of
which was an astoundingly un-

CHARLEY DER'S

believable ten-second pin.
Baltimore U's nine-point edge
over the Jays conceivably would
have been made up if Williams
had not been hurt. Marc would
have finished at least second,
and with fall points would have
given Hopkins enough to overcome the Bees.
While only finishing third in
the M-D tournament, Hopkins
still has a chance for the duel
meet championship with their 4-0
log, depending on the decision of
the league executive committee.
America U is also in contention
with a 6-0 record. The Jays'
Middle Atlantic record was even
up with a win over Drexel, a tie
with Dickinson and a loss to
Swarthmore. The grapplers will
not attend this weekend's tournament.
Three matmen were unbeaten
in dual-meet competition. Vic

Dates posted seven victories, Jim
Kelley five, all of them pins, and
Marc Williams five. The team
altogether took 26 falls and two
defaults, while losing only eight
falls.
The squad loses three seniors
this year and will be hard
pressed to replace them. Jim Errico, Vic , Dates and Marc Williams will all graduate. Ron
Davis at 123 and Art Pallazzo at
167 have the best freshman records. Randy Kunkel, Jack Goldstein and Norm Corkran will also
move up.
Coach Cochrane was gracious
in his praise of every team member and very justifiably so. The
whole season has been as pleasant as any coach could possibly
have.

bigotry. Indeed, these are many
vehemently called for concerted action to end this "repugnant practice" before the events of February 22.
Criticism from many quarters has been heaped upon
those students who led that stormy sit-in protest. The
action has been called rash, hurried, disorganized, unnecessary, etc. Yet where were all these "moderates"
with better methods of solving this knotty problem before
the demonstration?
One need not march with the sit-in group, or even
support such action. But as long as one is truly interested
in securing the, human rights of one's fellow students,
indeed, one's fellow man, one must recognize the efficacy
of the sit-in. For without the demonstration the problem
of discrimination would never have even entered the
minds of the great majority of people, the problem would
never have even been discussed in the numerous brotherhood meetings, and the many fine suggestions for less
dramatic action would never have been presented. Even
if the sit-in did not accomplish integration in one day,
it has accomplished a great deal in so far as it has brought
the problem to the surface for all to see and discuss.
It is unfortunate that so many individuals have taken
this opportunity to heap scorn on the sit-in when, indeed;
they owe a vote of thanks to it for calling attention to the
situation. The very fact that most have combined their
criticism with very informative, helpful alternative suggestions proves the effectiveness of the demonstration.
These suggestions would have never been put forth
otherwise.
One of the most discouraging aspects Of this affair
is the amazitig display of cowardice on the part of so
many when it came to taking action or voicing one's approval or disapproval of the situation. Many pre-sit-in
liberals smiled a cowardly refusal when asked to sign a
petition asserting their objection to discrimination. Why,
if one truly possesses the ideals and feelings that so many
claim to possess, must one cravenly hide them and reserve
them only for trusted friends—especially when one could
accomplish so much by speaking out freely.—B.R.

THE SEARCH FOR BRIDEY SIGAFOOS
It was a dullish evening at the Theta house. The pledges were
down in the catacombs; the actives were sacked out upstairs,
not doing much of anything. Mary Ellen Krumbald was sticking pins in an effigy of the housemother; Evelyn Zinsmaster
was welding a manhole cover to her charm bracelet; Algelica
McKeesport was writing a letter to Fabian in blood. Like I say,
it was a dullish evening.
Suddenly Dolores Vladnay stood up and stamped her foot.
"Chaps," she said to her sorors,"this is too yawn-making! Let's
do something gay and mad and gasp-making. Anybody got an
idea?"
"No," said the sorors, shaking their little sausage curls.
"Think, chaps, think!" said Dolores and passed Marlboro
Cigarettes to everybody, for if there ever was a smoke to start
you thinking, it is mild and flavorful Marlboro! Things come
clear when you puff that good, clean smoke through that fine
filter—knots untie, dilemmas dissolve, problems evaporate,
cobwebs vanish, fog disperses, and the benevolent sun pours

"Oh, capital!" cried the sorors. "Oh, tingle-making!"
At this point, in walked a young pledge named Alice Bluegown. "Excuse me, mistresses," said she, tugging her forelock,
"I have finished making your,beds, doing your homework, and
ironing your pleats. Will there be anything else?"
"Yes," snapped Dolores Vladna,y. "When I count to three,
you will be hypnotized."
"Yes, excellency," said Alice, bobbing a curtsey.
"One, two, three," said Dolores.
Alice promptly went into a trance.
"Go back," said Dolores, "back into your childhood. Go
back to your fifth birthday, back to your birth, to before your
birth, to your last incarnation ... Now, who are you?"
"My name is Bridey Sigafoos," said Alice. "The year is 1818,
and I am in County Cork."
"Coo!" said the sorors.
"How old are you?" asked Dblores.
"I am seven," said Alice.
"Where is your mother?" asked Dolores.
"I don't know," said Alice. "She got sold at the fair last
Year."
"Coo!" said the sorors.
"Tell us about yourself," said Dolores.
"I am five feet tall," said Alice. "I have brown eyes, and I
Weigh 3200 pounds."
"Coo!" said the sorors.
"Isn't that rather heavy for a girl?" said Dolores.
!'Who's a girl?" said Alice. "I'm a black and white guernsey.'
"Coo!" said the sorors.
"Moo!" said Bridey Sigafoos.

Heavyweight JIM KELLEY grapples with his opponent as the Jay wrestlers prepped last
week for Saturday's Mason-Dixon Tournament. Kelley finished second in his division, being
pinned by Baltimore U.'s kingpin Bill Kohlhafer in the final round, as the Homewood matmen
came up with third place in the tourney standings.

Jay Grapplers Close Season;
Make Good Tourney Showing
hours before the start of the
tournament, Senior Co-captain
Marc Williams suffered a bone
chip in his right ankle which
put him on crutches. Roger Morrison, undoubtedly the strongest
and most versatile substitute in
the conference, suffered a torn
ligament and was out of action.

On Tuesday, February 23, the
Hopkins freshman
basketball
team concluded its season with
a 51-to-39 victory over the Dickinson College J.V. This win was
the Jays' sixth straight since the
mid-semester break and ended
the cagers' season with an 11-3
record.
The team had - many high
points over the campaign among
them the two wins over Loyola,
by 66-to-58 and the overtime win
64-to-62. Also outstanding in the
minds of those who followed the
fortunes of the frosh basketball
team were the overtime victory
over Franklin and Marshall
frosh, 78-to-74, the first victory
in three years against Baltimore
Junior College, 67-to-63, and
last of all the miraculous and
well-played two-point loss to the
Navy Plebes 59-57.
Sulg Tops Club
The teams high scorer was
Jaan Sulg, who accumulated 223
points over the season. He averaged 43% from the floor and
72% from the line to lead the
squad in that category. Sulg had
two great games, scoring 30
points against Loyola and 28
against Franklin and Marshall.
Rick Saull combined with Sulg
to lead the offensive attack, scoring 212 points, while hitting for
a phenominal 49% from the floor
and 80% from the line. His best
performance of the season is
hard to pick out as he averaged
in double figures in all of the
contests. Saull not only lent his
wight to the offensive surge but
greatly aided the defensive department, leading in rebounds
with 135, which is close to tena-game. He was second high in
the scoring department, averaging 15.1 points a game.

Guts. There might be nicer
ways to say it, but there isn't
a more descriptive way ... Guts
is what it took to work out for
two years with no official team,
sparse facilities, no letter awards,
no schedule, and sometimes not
even somebody else to wrestle
with, and guts carried the Hopkins wrestling team to third
place in the Mason-Dixon Conference tournament after the
team saw two of its best grapplers injured on the day before
the meet, automatically causing
the forfeiture of the 191-1b. class.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MARCH 4, 1960

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE EIGHT

BLUE JAY GRAPPLERS Frosh Dribblers End Year
POST WINNING SEASON With Victory For 11-3 Log
(Continued from Page 7)
his initial loss and from there on
he was very effective.
Jim Kelley, always the team
leader in no matter what sport
he plays, put on a superb exhibition of wrestling skill to capture the runner-up spot in the
Conference for the second year
in a row. Once again Baltimore
U's gargantuan Dick Kohlhafer,
who was voted the outstanding
tourney wrestler, pinned Kelley.
This heavyweight bout was undoubtedly the feature and highlight of the whole tournament.
For over four minutes, these
two fabulous performers traded
positions, while the crowd held
its breath. Kohlhafer, incidentally, has only failed to pin a
man once in his entire career,
and that man weighed 310
pounds. Kelley captured nine key
points for the Blue Jays, seven
for being runner-up and two for
his pair of previous falls, one of
which was an astoundingly un-

CHARLEY DER'S

believable ten-second pin.
Baltimore U's nine-point edge
over the Jays conceivably would
have been made up if Williams
had not been hurt. Marc would
have finished at least second,
and with fall points would have
given Hopkins enough to overcome the Bees.
While only finishing third in
the M-D tournament, Hopkins
still has a chance for the duel
meet championship with their 4-0
log, depending on the decision of
the league executive committee.
America U is also in contention
with a 6-0 record. The Jays'
Middle Atlantic record was even
up with a win over Drexel, a tie
with Dickinson and a loss to
Swarthmore. The grapplers will
not attend this weekend's tournament.
Three matmen were unbeaten
in dual-meet competition. Vic

Dates posted seven victories, Jim
Kelley five, all of them pins, and
Marc Williams five. The team
altogether took 26 falls and two
defaults, while losing only eight
falls.
The squad loses three seniors
this year and will be hard
pressed to replace them. Jim Errico, Vic , Dates and Marc Williams will all graduate. Ron
Davis at 123 and Art Pallazzo at
167 have the best freshman records. Randy Kunkel, Jack Goldstein and Norm Corkran will also
move up.
Coach Cochrane was gracious
in his praise of every team member and very justifiably so. The
whole season has been as pleasant as any coach could possibly
have.
